dt: {bc}{d_link|deviating|deviate:1} from the usual or natural type {bc}{sx|atypical||}, {sx|abnormal||}

dt.t: I don't intend to suggest that his psychology was in some way {wi}aberrant{/wi} or neurotic …

dt: {bc}straying from the right or normal way

quotes.t: … at the brief and {qword}aberrant{/qword} moment in time when it was possible to believe that America owed its great place in the world to its military and moral virtue rather than to the weight of its currency.
… as if he had happily spied an {qword}aberrant{/qword} crocus amid the wintry gray scene of Presidential impeachment.

The stones, silvered in the moon's {qword}aberrant{/qword} light, shone like spectral tombs, and the figures, which Dalgliesh knew were Helena, Lettie and the Bostocks, became discarnate shapes disappearing into the darkness.

et: borrowed from Latin {it}aberrant-, aberrans{/it}, present participle of {it}aberrāre{/it} "to wander away, stray, go wrong," from {it}ab-{/it} {et_link|ab-|ab-} + {it}errāre{/it} "to wander, drift, be in error" {ma}{mat|err|}{/ma}
shortdef: deviating from the usual or natural type : atypical, abnormal
straying from the right or normal way

dt: {bc}a group, individual, or structure that is not normal or typical {bc}an aberrant group, individual, or structure
{bc}a person whose behavior departs substantially from the standard

shortdef: a group, individual, or structure that is not normal or typical : an aberrant group, individual, or structure
a person whose behavior departs substantially from the standard
